Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Electronic and Optical Properties of Nanostructures Built with Atomic Precision
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical abstract:
To realize the promise of nanostructured materials for applications in information technology, medicine and energy, an atomic-level understanding of nanostructure properties is needed. This Faculty Early Career program focuses on nanoscience research, education and outreach at Ohio State University. Scanning tunneling microscopy is used to study metal nanoclusters and molecular wires which are potentially future building blocks for nanoscale devices. These microscopes have unique capabilities suitable for studying nanostructure properties as their size, shape, and local environment are varied on the atomic scale. This research is integrated with educational and outreach activities at Ohio State which target underrepresented undergraduates, high school students and the public. Classroom lectures, research demonstrations and outreach presentations are delivered to remote locations using web-based Access Grid videoconferencing tools. These efforts will improve participation and training of students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) related fields.

Technical abstract:
To realize the promise of nanostructured materials for applications in information technology, medicine and energy, an atomic-level understanding of nanostructure properties is needed. Scanning tunneling microscopy is used to study how quantum size effects, atomic structure and coupling to the local environment influence the electronic and optical properties of metal nanoclusters. These influences are systematically studied with atomic-resolution imaging, tunneling/optical spectroscopy and atom/molecule manipulation. Metal nanoclusters form atomically-precise contacts for studies of current flow through single molecules. This research is integrated with educational and outreach activities at Ohio State which target underrepresented undergraduates, high school students and the general public. Classroom lectures, research demonstrations and outreach presentations are delivered to remote locations using web-based Access Grid videoconferencing tools. These efforts will improve participation and training of students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The continuing development of information and energy technologies relies on an improved understanding of nanometer-size structures (1 nm = 10-9 m). This NSF CAREER program involved the study of nanostructures that could be imaged with atomic resolution and assembled one atom at a time using advanced scanned probe microscopy techniques. This degree of control allowed us to study how the electronic and magnetic properties of the structures varied with size, composition and interactions with neighbor structures in new ways. For example, we studied how materials properties first develop from constituent atoms. An individual atom is neither conducting nor insulating; these are collective properties that arise when “many” atoms are put together. One question that drives our research is: How many?  We have demonstrated that an insulator’s band gap can develop in one layer thick nanoislands comprising only tens of atoms. Such ‘ultrathin’ insulating films represent a fundamental limit for the scaling of transistors in computer chips. One common theme that developed during the program was the close correspondence possible between the experiments and advanced modeling using supercomputers. This synergy provided further insight into the underlying physics of these nanosystems that wouldn’t have otherwise been possible.

 

The fundamental research serves as a backdrop for the recruitment and training of a next generation of scientists that span demographic groups and bring a diverse experience to bear on these problems. Web-based technologies were employed to reach a broad and diverse audience that so far, numbers greater than 750 high school students in 8 U.S. states, as well as Alberta province, Canada. At the next stage, undergraduate students were introduced to research throughout the program with NSF funding. Recently, the PI has joined a taskforce charged with developing a bridge program to help students from underrepresented groups succeed in graduate school. NSF funding was also used to support postdoctoral researchers and provide additional professional development. The multidisciplinary nature of this project has given the graduate, postdoctoral and undergraduate students a broad spectrum of experiences that prepares them for careers in industry, academia, and government. Students must not only integrate concepts from traditional disciplines such as physics, chemistry, materials science, and electrical engineering, but be able to clearly communicate ideas as active members of the community at-large.
